comments.commentBody: The sympathetic nervous system resonates to different tonal registers with differing emotion-like responses. The higher register of the violin, or soprano voice evokes the ethereal. Mid-range – viola, english horn, etc. – elicits a response that resembles sentiment or nostalgia. The lower registers, 'cello or guitar, calls forth passion, and we all know that the drummer gets the girl. Now we know why. The neurology of the body vibrates sympathetically, and the mind provides the emotional correspondence. We could see music as a universal language.

Martin,

It is the octopus (Paula) who chooses what door is to be opened, not the handler. The handler may not be anywhere close to the door that was opened. In the next round the handler has to move over one side either clockwise or counterclockwise to where he was. On the other hand, Paula is free to open any door that she wishes, even one that is far away from the previous one.

I hope that's clearer.
I miss Bob Murphy!

he he!

good to see that one person still likes philly

Get rid of the bum. There are already too many brats in professional sports. I'm tired of them outshining the real athletes.

Admittedly, it took me several viewings to see what this "tripping" was all about. For those slow learners, like me, Alosi bent his leg and jutted his knee into Carroll's path. Once I saw that, I realized how egregious Alosi's action was. What a juvenile.

I have a simple solution. Instead of bickering or trying to reinvent the wheel, why not give every citizen the same health care plan Congress has. It's so affordable that even the homeless can come up with the monthly premiums. How will the government fit it in the budget? I don't know, but it manages to keep paying for two wars with no end in sight.

There is precedence in mandating everyone's having health care insurance. It is called Medicare Part D Prescription Drug coverage. If one does not buy Part D coverage from a private insurer and later chooses to do so, there is a very stiff penalty that will be levied for the rest of one's life. This is a mandate with a threat of penalty.

I have not had a drug prescription for 25 years but I was mandated to buy drug coverage from insurance companies that raise their rates every year (this year mine was increased 100%). The insurance companies are making a killing off senior citizens as a gift from the Republicans who eagerly wrote a mandate into the bill in 2005. David of NYC writes, "If this wasn't ruled unconstitutional, this law would be the first law in our history that required citizens to buy a commercial product." WRONG, David. I am required by law--mandated-- to purchase a commercial product under penalty of law.

There's a far simpler way to handle this.
We aren't required to buy "government mandated military insurance"
The defense department is funded directly from our taxes.
The same thing should be done for protection of citizens from the greatest threat to the safety of America's citizens -- disease. We pay taxes. In return the govenment contracts to protect our lives to enable us to have liberty and persue happiness.
America's first reponsibility to its citizens, even before our national defense is our national defense against disease.
The best rational calculus for cold hard choices of where to spend our tax dollars demands it.
The Constitution ALSO has little respect for stare decisis.
And how much did it cost this country for all these lawsuits over such a poorly-drafted and obviously unconstitutional bill?  Money that could have gone to... duh... providing healthcare.

Thank you, Gawd. As a wellness minded person, who grew up around medicare, it would habe been a circus of people trying to get their money's worth in vicodin and valium. To start. Thrre was no incentive for people to take care, unlike car insurance. And the fed gov admitted, AFTER PASSING IT, that it would cost more than insurance now.
The AARP says that people over fifty have 85% of the wealth, yet they wanted the young to subdidize them.
If you like allopathic medicine, check out Hawai's plans. Half the national price! when many costs are more. Anyone working 20 hours a week plus gets a free policy. Yep, Walmart pays health insurance for its employees there.
If you dont even work that much but have income twice the fpl you get medical AND DENTAL.

There are many healthy people in this world who have never needed a doctor. I'll cast my example with theirs instead of the lady complaining on a previous related article that this doesn't cover free stomach-stapling.
Wishing you well from Hawaii!

What few here seem to understand is that Obamacare isn't federally provided health care. It is federally mandated insurance. Those aren't the the same thing. This is why those of you who are complaining that" if other countries provide health care" miss the point and simply don't understand what the so called health care bill was about. IT WASN"T A HEALTH CARE BILL! IT WAS AN INSURANCE MANDATE! And health insurance isn't health care any more than car insurance is car care. Health insurance is only a means in which the costs of health care are distributed.

Had the congress and the administration desired to mandate a health care plan (as in medicare for all) there would have been no constitutional problem. Instead, congress simply mandated that we all purchase health insurance. See the distinction?

David NYC "Auto insurance can be mandated because the gov't is not requiring you to buy an car."

The government is mandating you buy insurance (commodity as in this lawsuit) if you own a car though. Its the exact same principle under the law. You cannot separate them.

If you strike down one you open up lawsuits to strike down any federal mandated requirements.

It wasn't unexpected Am I right?

Let see when the supreme court takes over this subject.

Theoretically mandating a person to buy a commercial product is unconstitutional.

Practically you the poor people , your right to have health care is unconstitutional either.

Ain't it so?

What?! Can we also infer that mandatory automobile insurance is unconstitutional? The entire health and insurance issue is critical to the future of U.S both economically and medically. It is incredibly painful and super frustrating to see our future destroyed by pure ideology without regard to human need and/or condition. Wow. Just wait until it's your nearest and dearest. It will take more than a tea party to right this wrong.
Just another example of political posturing. When will we ever decide to do what is best for the country?

It is like auto insurance in that other people pay for you if you have no insurance.Then, every one else pays more. . The ER idea is not a good one. People need preventive care and follow-up. If you take your minor complaints to the ER , every other patient will be paying for you, not only in tax dollars, but because you take up a bed that sick people need, and you steal the staff's time which other people need emergently. Come to the ED only if you are really ill . Be a mensch.
I suppose that this ruling will be the one that the Supreme Court chooses to rule on. Too bad neither Alito nor Thomas seem likely to off the court by then. Please retire, gentlemen.
.

I voted for Obama, but was sadly disappointed in the Health Care Bill.  Obama and the Democrats really caved to pressure and didn't fight for Single Payer.  Instead there is this mis-mash wreck of a bill, with the ridiculous provision requiring citizens to buy a private health insurance product.  Medicare and Social Security are different - they are taxes, and the U.S. Govt has power to levy taxes as it needs.  There is also no requirement for Seniors to have Medicare - if they don't sign up, the coverage becomes more expensive each year they delay.  I think Single Payer could work this way too - tax everyone wages a certain percentage, maybe 2%?  And then they can sign up for Single Payer, if they don't do it, then they pay more later.

I use to care, but not anymore.  As a retired Postal employee, I benefit from the same health care options as our elected officials.  I am friends of numerous younger people that do not have health care insurance because their employers do not offer insurance.  But, during the last election, not one of them voted.  The Democratic party spends too much of their time representing the lower class - the vary ones who do not vote.  Until the lower income individuals start to vote regularly, the Democratics are facing doom.  And I do not care.  I have been a Democratic supporter for my entire life, but we are now doomed - but will never vote for a Republican.  Tax cuts and abortion does not solve all our country's ills, but that is the only cause Republicans have.  Oh, I forgot WAR!
At last, a voice of reason.

"I just want people to realize that they are all part of the health care system and there is no "electing" not to be part of it because we are all sick and/or injured at sometime in our lives. I'm sorry - you play, you pay; and believe me, everyone plays eventually."

This is a sentiment I agree with wholeheartedly. Also, I believe that establishing a national health care system for ALL in which ALL citizens participate and in which ALL share in the costs as well as benefits will be the greatest and most unifying accomplishment this nation has ever made.

I don't understand why hospitals and care providers are legally required to provide healthcare - for example, an accident victim or someone seriously sick who shows up in an emergency room - but those same people are not required to carry some form of health insurance that pays for these services.  I've got no problem with someone not carrying health insurance as long as the rest of us don't get stuck with the bill when these same people show up in the ER.

We have to realize that not every thing in life is for profit. We will not be able to draw water, to have heat or cook what little food we have if everything is about profit. Forget about health care. They want us to die. It increases the bottom line.

I'm 42, uninsured and have a pre-existing "condition".

You know what?

I don't want to have to buy health insurance either.

Give me nationalized health care or give me a gun so I can shoot myself if and when the time comes.

Why wasn't Judge Henry E. Hudson's ownership interest in the anti Health Care PR firm, Campaign Solutions revealed in this story? And what about Cuccinelli, the A.G. who filed the case, having been a client of this PR firm? At minimum an appearance of impropriety.
